data.title: How to Write an R&B Song: A Songwriting Step-by-Step Guide
meta_keywords: How to Write an R&B Song
data.meta_description: Learn how to write an R&B song with Tai Andrews' step-by-step guide. Craft soulful melodies, evocative lyrics, and captivating R&B chords. Get inspired and start writing your next hit today!
data.text:
As a singer or songwriter, writing an R&B song allows you to express your emotions and captivate listeners with your soulful voice. Over the years, R&B has evolved to become one of the most popular genres of music globally, with many songs making it to the top of mainstream charts like the Billboard Hot 100. But what makes a hit R&B song?

In this article, we will walk you through the step by step process of How To Write an R&B Song.

Key Takeaways

Understand the importance of choosing an R&B scale that complements the mood of your song.

Incorporate R&B chords and extensions, such as major 7th, minor 7th, and dominant 7th chords.

Experiment with R&B progressions.

Write authentic and evocative lyrics that reflect R&B themes.

Blend traditional R&B elements with modern songwriting techniques.

How To Write an R&B Song – Quick Look

1. Choose the Right Scale and Chords

Select an R&B scale that complements the mood of your song, such as the major pentatonic or mixolydian scale.

Incorporate R&B chords and extensions like major 7th, minor 7th, and dominant 7th chords.

Experiment with common R&B chord progressions such as I-iv-V-vi and II-V-I.

2. Write Authentic Lyrics

Draw inspiration from your personal experiences.

Create relatable lyrics that express R&B themes like love, heartbreak, and relationships.

3. Structure Your Song

Intro: Set the mood with an interesting musical or vocal hook.

Verse: Begin your story with a memorable melody and rhythm. Use metaphors, wordplay, and descriptive language.

Pre-Chorus (optional): Build anticipation for the chorus with different chords, melodies, and rhythms.

Chorus: Make it the emotional core of your song with memorable lines and a strong melody.

4. Use Pre-Made R&B Beats (Optional)

Explore various beats: Listen to different pre-made R&B beats to find one that fits the mood and style of your song.

Customize the beat: Modify and personalize the beat if possible to make it unique to your song.

Integrate the beat: Seamlessly blend the chosen beat with your melody and lyrics to complete your R&B track.

To write a heartfelt R&B song, draw inspiration from your experiences and weave them into relatable lyrics. Let your voice convey the emotions through smooth melodies and soulful chords.

Experiment with scales like major pentatonic and mixolydian, and chord progressions like I-iv-V-vi and II-V-I. Let your passion guide you as you create music that touches hearts and leaves a lasting impression.

Tai Andrews

let’s dive deeper.

What is R&B?

R&B, or Rhythm and Blues, is a genre deeply rooted in African American music traditions. It combines elements of gospel, jazz, and blues. For artists like Summer Walker, SZA, and Giveon, R&B provides a rich musical canvas.

R&B is characterized by:

Emotional Singing: Artists convey deep emotions through their vocals, making it a genre that thrives on passion and vulnerability.

Irresistible Beats: R&B’s rhythms make you want to move, giving it a distinct groove.

Catchy Melodies: Memorable and sultry melodies are a hallmark of contemporary R&B.

R&B has evolved into various styles, from soul and funk to disco, neo-soul, and contemporary R&B. Legendary figures like Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin, and Michael Jackson have paved the way for modern stars like Bruno Mars, Beyoncé and The Weeknd.

Today’s talents such as SZA, Summer Walker, Giveon, Khalid, Bryson Tiller, Lucky Daye, and Snoh Aalegra continue to shape the genre with fresh approaches.

At its core, R&B explores themes of love, heartbreak, and relationships. It’s a universal language that touches the soul and makes you feel good, as Marvin Gaye once sang.

Instant Cheat Sheet: Premade R&B Beats

Ever find yourself staring at an empty sheet of paper, with nothing but a blank canvas and a blank mind? If you’re a songwriter who struggles with writer’s block, pre-made beats can be your secret weapon to unlock creativity and ignite your musical spark.

Pre-made beats act like springboards for your songwriting journey, providing a solid rhythm and vibe to guide your creative flow.

Instead of getting overwhelmed by creating a beat from scratch, you can focus on the heart of your song – the lyrics, melodies, and emotions you want to express. Using these can help you learn how to write an RnB song.

How to Write an R&B Song: The Basics

R&B Song Structure and Music

The Verse – Telling the Story

The Verse – Where the Story Starts

Think of the verse in an R&B song as the beginning of a story. It’s usually a short part with a consistent melody and rhythm.

This is where the singer gets creative. They use comparisons, clever wordplay, and colorful descriptions to make the story interesting. It’s like a canvas where they paint their feelings and experiences for you to hear.

Metaphors help express complex emotions, wordplay adds a fun twist, and descriptive words make you feel like you’re part of the story. The verse is where the singer connects with you, setting the stage for what comes next in the chorus. It’s the start of the story and the journey of emotions.

Using Sza as an example again. SZA’s verses in “Good Days” are a masterclass in R&B storytelling. The lyrics are introspective and contemplative, touching on themes of self-discovery and personal growth.

Lines like “I still wanna try, still believe in good days” convey a sense of hope and resilience, a common thread in modern R&B songs.

The Pre-Chorus – Build Anticipation

The pre-chorus is an optional section that comes before the chorus. It’s usually a short part that transitions from the verse to the chorus, building anticipation and excitement for the main hook.

The pre-chorus can use different chords, melodies, and rhythms than the verse and chorus, creating contrast and tension. It can also introduce a new lyrical idea or theme, setting up the chorus.

For example, in “No Guidance” by Chris Brown and Drake, the pre-chorus features a catchy melody and a clever wordplay on the word “guidance”, leading to the chorus that expresses their confidence and charisma.

The Chorus – The Heart of the Song

The chorus is the emotional core of your song, repeating several times to create a lasting impact. It usually consists of four to eight lines, each with a different melody and rhythm compared to the verse.

In “Say My Name” by Destiny’s Child, the use of repetition and contrast ensures a memorable and emotional chorus.

Say my name, say my name

If no one is around you, say “Baby, I love you”

If you ain’t runnin’ game

Say my name, say my name

You actin’ kinda shady, ain’t callin’ me baby

Why the sudden change?

Say My Name, Destiny’s Child

The chorus in “Girls Need Love” is where Summer Walker’s emotive vocals take center stage. With lines like “Girls can’t never say they want it, girls can’t never say how,” the chorus encapsulates the song’s message of desire and the importance of open communication in relationships.

The repetition and Summer Walker’s evocative delivery make it the emotional core of the song, resonating with listeners who can relate to its themes.

The Bridge – Adding Variety and Tension

The bridge introduces variety and tension into your song. It typically appears after the second or third chorus and differs significantly from the verse and chorus in terms of melody, rhythm, and chord progression.

The bridge can be used to change the mood, perspective, or direction of your song, adding a twist or a surprise. It can also be used to heighten the emotion, drama, or climax of your song, leading to the final chorus.

For example, in “Halo” by Beyoncé, the bridge features a key change and a soaring vocal, creating a powerful and uplifting moment.

The Outro – Making a Lasting Impression

The outro is your song’s conclusion, wrapping up the message and leaving a lasting impact. It can repeat the chorus, offer a variation of the intro, or introduce a new section.

For instance, in “I Will Always Love You” by Whitney Houston, the outro repeats the chorus with a more powerful vocal, fading out with a long and powerful note, creating a dramatic and emotional ending.

Melody: The Soul of an R&B Song

What’s the secret to making an R&B song stand out and stay in your memory? It’s the tune. Imagine the tune as the heartbeat of the song, the part that lingers in your mind even after the music has faded away.

The tune sets the mood for the entire song, like the background in a painting that creates the overall feeling. When the tune is catchy and stays with you, it’s like a pleasant memory that’s not easy to forget.

So, when you come across a fantastic tune in an R&B song, it’s akin to the joy you feel when you hear your favorite song. It remains with you long after the music has ended. That’s what makes R&B music so unforgettable and special.

Chords: Adding Depth and Emotion

R&B songs use special chords to add depth and emotion to the music.

Scales: Crafting a Unique Character

R&B melodies draw from specific scales that give the music its unique character. Here are some essential scales:

Dorian Mode: This scale adds a soulful and jazzy touch to the song, creating a distinctive R&B sound.

Mixolydian Mode: It infuses a bluesy and groovy feel, contributing to the genre’s unique groove.

Blues Scale: This scale brings deep emotions into R&B music, connecting with listeners on a profound level.

Progression: Creativity and Unpredictability

R&B progressions are known for their creativity and unpredictability. Here’s how they achieve this:

Smooth Transitions: Chords flow seamlessly from one to the next, creating a melodic and connected feel.

Surprising Chord Choices: R&B often uses unexpected chords, adding excitement and freshness to the music.

Reimagined Classics: Musicians in R&B put their twist on classic chord patterns, like the ii-V-I progression, combining familiarity with innovation.

How to Write an R&B Chorus

Crafting a catchy R&B chorus is essential for any songwriter or producer. In this concise guide, we’ll explore the essential steps to create an unforgettable R&B chorus, drawing from my extensive experience in beat production and songwriting.

Step 1: Repetition for Catchiness

Repetition is a fundamental technique in R&B music. It’s the secret sauce that makes a chorus memorable. For instance, in Usher’s “Yeah!”, he repeats “yeah” three times, creating an effective hook. To make your R&B chorus catchy:

Repeat Key Words or Phrases: Choose a central word or phrase from your song and use repetition in the chorus to make it memorable.

Step 2: The Art of Rhyming

Rhyming is essential for a smooth and harmonious R&B chorus. In Alicia Keys’ “No One,” words like “one,” “done,” and “sun” are rhymed to perfection. To add rhythm and flow to your chorus:

Identify Rhyming Words: Find words in your lyrics that naturally rhyme, enhancing the musical quality of your chorus.

Step 3: Embrace Simplicity

Simplicity often works best in R&B music. Keep your chorus straightforward and relatable. Remember, less is more when crafting a memorable chorus:

Keep It Simple: Use clear and impactful language that resonates with your audience, avoiding unnecessary complexity.

How to Write an R&B Verse

Creating a great R&B verse is important. Here’s how to do it with simple tips:

Stick to the Theme: Make sure your verse fits with what your song is about. Don’t talk about unrelated things; it confuses people. For example: Good Verse: “We danced all night under the city lights, your smile shining bright, everything feels right.” This is good because it fits the love theme and creates a nice picture. Bad Verse: “I went to the store, bought more, the sky was blue, tied my shoe, my dog barked, people walked through, I forgot my line, it’s all askew.” This verse is bad because it talks about unrelated things and is confusing.

Get Their Attention: Start your verse with a catchy line. It’s like a hook that grabs your listeners.

Paint Pictures: Use words that help people imagine what’s happening in your verse.

Use Cool Words: Try comparing things in a neat way or using words that have more than one meaning. It makes your verse more interesting.

Make It Flow: Each line should fit well with the one before and after. Your verse should tell a clear story or message.

Share Your Feelings: Put your own experiences and emotions into your verse. It makes your music relatable and real.

Keep Improving: Don’t be afraid to change and make your verse better. Sometimes, the best lines come after a few tries.

By following these simple steps and looking at the examples, you can write verses that connect with your audience and make your R&B song shine.

How to Write an R&B Bridge

Creating a strong R&B bridge is important to keep your audience engaged. Here are easy steps to make a powerful bridge:

Change It Up: Make the bridge different from the rest of the song. Use a unique melody, rhythm, or instruments to grab attention.

Build Tension: Create excitement with your lyrics, melodies, or chords. The bridge should get listeners excited for the final chorus.

Make It Emotional: Focus on the main emotion of your song in the bridge. Talk about a feeling or experience that matches the song’s message.

Add Vocal Flair: Try vocal techniques like harmonies, ad-libs, or vocal runs to bring emotion to the bridge.

How to Write an R&B Outro

A memorable R&B outro leaves a strong impression. Here’s how to create a great outro:

Wrap It Up: Summarize your song’s main message or theme in the outro. Make sure your listeners understand what the song is about.

Show Emotion: Focus on the song’s main feeling in the outro. You can do this with your singing style or instruments.

Fade Out Smoothly: Gradually lower the volume of the music to give your song a nice ending.

Final Chorus Twist: Consider going back to the final chorus but with a new twist in your singing or music.

Repeat Hooks: Repeating a catchy phrase from your song in the outro makes it more memorable.

Instrumental Outros: If your song is mainly music, use the outro to show off your musical skills with a cool instrumental solo.

How to Write an R&B Song: Capturing the Feel

Step 1: Feel the Emotion

Immerse yourself in the emotions of your R&B song. Think about your personal experiences or universal feelings that can connect with your audience.

Step 2: Choose the Right Scale

Pick an R&B scale that fits the mood of your song. You can go for the Dorian, Mixolydian, or blues scale to give your song that soulful touch.

Step 3: Add Rich Chords

Use R&B chords and extensions to add depth and richness to your music. Try major 7th, minor 7th, and other extended chords to create that R&B flavor.

Step 4: Create Harmonic Progressions

Experiment with R&B progressions to establish the foundation of your song. Smooth voice leading and unexpected chord changes can make your song stand out.

Step 5: Craft Soulful Melodies

Create melodies that showcase your vocal style and emotion. Use techniques like melisma and vocal runs to add that R&B flair.

Step 6: Write Authentic Lyrics

Compose lyrics that reflect R&B themes like love, heartbreak, and self-reflection. Use imagery and storytelling to connect with your audience.

Step 7: Blend R&B with Modern Production

Combine traditional R&B elements with modern production techniques to create a contemporary sound. Experiment with electronic textures, effects, and innovative rhythms to give your song a fresh twist.

How to Write R&B Lyrics

Words to Use in an R&B Song

R&B lyrics often use a special vocabulary that sets the tone for the genre’s soulful and heartfelt vibe. Here are some popular words and phrases that are commonly used in R&B music and why they add depth and authenticity to your lyrics:

Metaphors and Similes: R&B songwriters often use metaphors and similes to compare their emotions and experiences to natural elements or everyday objects. For instance, “Love is like a warm summer breeze” or “My heart is a broken record” are classic metaphors that evoke the intensity of love and the pain of heartbreak.

Phonological Devices: R&B lyrics often utilize phonological devices, such as alliteration (the repetition of consonant sounds) and assonance (the repetition of vowel sounds), to create a smooth and melodic flow.

Imagery and Sensory Details: R&B lyrics often paint vivid pictures in the listener’s mind by using imagery and sensory details. For instance, describing the “taste of your lips, a sweet summer kiss” or “the scent of your perfume, a lingering bliss” allows the listener to connect with the story on a deeper level.

Idioms and Slang: R&B music has its own unique slang and idioms that add a touch of authenticity and relatability. For example, phrases like “feeling down but you’re the sunshine after the rain” or “so smitten, I can’t help but put a ring on it” are common in R&B lyrics and instantly connect with listeners who share the same experiences.

Musical Terms and References: Subtle references to musical terms or concepts can add depth and credibility to your R&B lyrics. For instance, using phrases like “funky groove” or “sweet harmonies” subtly showcases your knowledge of the genre and enhances the overall R&B vibe of your song.

Crafting a Compelling Story

R&B songs often tell relatable stories that resonate with listeners. Here are some tips for crafting a compelling narrative in your R&B lyrics:

Structure and Pacing: R&B songs typically follow a clear structure, often with verses, bridges, and a chorus. The verses tell the story, the bridges provide emotional depth, and the chorus summarizes the main theme.

Relateability: The story should be something that others can understand or connect with. Think about universal emotions or experiences that people can relate to, such as love, loss, or the challenges of life.

Character Development: If your song has characters, develop them in a way that makes them relatable and believable. Show their thoughts, feelings, and actions so that listeners can connect with them on an emotional level.

Vivid Storytelling: Use vivid imagery and descriptive language to paint a picture in the listener’s mind. Use sensory details, such as sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and textures, to immerse the listener in the story.

Example: In Mary J. Blige’s “Real Love,” she tells a story of a woman facing the ups and downs of a relationship. It’s relatable because many people have been through similar experiences.

By following these simple tips and using examples, you can create R&B lyrics that express your feelings and tell stories people can connect with. Keep it real and let your creativity flow.

Making Money as an R&B Songwriter

How to Monetize Your R&B Music as a Songwriter

As an R&B songwriter, it is essential to understand how to monetize your music. Platforms like Spotify, Apple Music, and Tidal offer music streaming options that allow you to monetize your music through royalties.

Additionally, uploading your music on music licensing platforms like Songtradr or AudioJungle can help you monetize your music through.

Here are key methods to generate income:

Streaming Platforms: Utilize platforms like Spotify, Apple Music, and Tidal to monetize your music through royalties. Building a strong presence on these platforms is essential to maximize your streaming revenue.

Music Licensing: Upload your music on licensing platforms like Songtradr or AudioJungle to secure licensing deals for commercials, films, and other media projects, providing an additional revenue stream beyond traditional royalties.

Live Performances: Engage in live performances at concerts, festivals, and events to earn income from ticket sales and merchandise, while also expanding your fan base.

Merchandise Sales: Create and sell merchandise such as t-shirts, hats, and physical copies of your music at live shows and online to enhance your revenue.

Sync Opportunities: Explore sync opportunities in TV shows, movies, and advertisements to increase your earnings and exposure.

Collaborations and Co-Writing: Collaborate with other artists and producers to access new revenue streams through royalties and co-writing credits.

Online Engagement and Crowdfunding: Build a strong online presence, engage with your fans through social media and streaming platforms, and consider crowdfunding opportunities on platforms like Patreon and Kickstarter to boost your music sales and earnings1.

Diversifying your income streams and actively promoting your music are key to maximizing your earnings as an R&B songwriter.

Conclusion

Writing an R&B song can be a rewarding and enjoyable experience. You can express your feelings, tell a story, and create a musical masterpiece.

By following the steps in this guide, you can learn the basics of R&B songwriting and develop your own style and voice.

Remember to practice, experiment, and have fun with your music. You never know, you might end up writing the next hit song!
